_EnemyFeatures: Tempered Rathian
_FirstCapture:
Fire-breathing female wyverns known as
the \Queens of the Land." Their powerful
legs and venomous tails make them
efficient ground hunters. At times
_Memo: Rathian\r\nand Rathalos can be sighted hunting as a\r\ncouple. After laying eggs
_Grammar: Rathian are\r\nextremely watchful of their nests. Proceed\r\nwith extra caution
_BossIconType: as a mother will move\r\nswiftly to protect her young."
_ZakoIconType:
Hunters will need to maneuver carefully
to avoid the potent venom in the
Rathian's tail spikes and her wide
attack range. By severing the tail, you
can limit her reach and gain the upper
hand. After breathing fire, the inside
of the Rathian's mouth becomes tender,
making it a prime target to strike.

_EnemyExp: Fearsome wyverns known as \Kings of the Skies.\"\r\nArmed with powerful poison claws
_EnemyExtraName: they use their\r\naerial prowess to descend on prey from above."
_EnemyTips: Fearsome male wyverns known as the\r\n\Kings of the Skies.\" Alongside the Rathian
_FirstCapture: \r\nthey stake out a wide territory around their\r\nnests
_Memo: and it is the male\'s role to watch\r\nfrom above. Armed with powerful poisonous\r\nclaws and fiery breath
_Grammar: Rathalos use their\r\naerial prowess to descend on invaders."
_BossIconType:
As Kings of the Skies, Rathalos will attack
with a variety of aerial strikes. A bright
flash should be enough to disorient them
and bring them down. When Rathalos
are in trouble, their Rathian mates may
swoop in to help, so be sure to have dung
pods and large dung pods at the ready.

_EnemyExp: An artificial species created by an ancient\r\ncivilization with a Rathalos\'s power. Beware the\r\nenergy released by their powerful claw attacks.
_EnemyFeatures:
An artificial monster species created by
an ancient civilization and imbued with
Rathalos's power. Guardian Rathalos cannot
reproduce and do not require food, relying
instead on Wyvern Milk for energy. Just like
the original Rathalos, they are superior
fliers and will attack more violently with
their claws while airborne.
_EnemyTips:
The unique Guardian energy from Guardian
Rathalos's claw attacks is explosive and
dangerous. This energy will cause wyvern
milk on the ground to crystalize, and if
these crystals are hit by the monster's fire
attacks it will cause an explosion of the
same element. Given that they are triggered
by elemental interference, Slinger ammo
could be used effectively against them.

_EnemyExp: Large wyverns found in the Oilwell Basin.\r\nTheir highly developed carapaces repel\r\nattacks and emit powerful heat rays.
_EnemyFeatures:
Large wyverns found in Oilwell Basin. They
have a developed physique, powerful heat
rays, and a host of gases they can emit
from their body. Their bony carapaces are
famously tough but expose a surprisingly
brittle interior once destroyed.
_EnemyTips:
It's no easy task breaking through that
heavy armor covering a Gravios head to
talon, but repeated attacks will eventually
make a crack. That\u{2014}and the weaknesses
a Gravios exposes in its carapace during
certain attacks\u{2014}are your chances to deliver
Focus Strikes, demolish it piece by piece,
and create even more opportunities.

_EnemyExp: Bird wyverns with impressive beaks, big ears,\r\nand an appetite for insects. Skittish by nature,\r\nthey will still put up a fight if threatened.
_EnemyFeatures:
Bird wyverns with impressive beaks and
large ears. They tend to be skittish but will
sometimes initiate attacks on a perceived
threat. Yian Kut-Ku arrive in large groups
during the season of Plenty in the Scarlet
Forest. The absence of eggs or young
suggests that the purpose of this is not
to breed, but rather to seek out mates
and nourishment.
_EnemyTips:
The Yian Kut-Ku's superior hearing comes
with great sensitivity to sound. A loud
noise is sometimes all it takes to stop them
in their tracks, reason enough to make
liberal use of sonic bombs. But there's a
catch: once a Yian Kut-Ku comes back to
itself, it's going to be really flocking mad
and come at a hunter even more viciously
than before.

_EnemyExp: Monsters that use their prominent crest to stun\r\nfoes with disorienting flashes of light before\r\nfinishing them off with poisonous saliva.
_EnemyFeatures:
Wyverns that can stun enemies by striking
their prominent crests to produce powerful
flashes of light. Their stretchy, rubbery
hide resists blunt impacts and reduces the
effectiveness of shock traps. A smart hunter
knows to maneuver carefully around the
poisonous filth they spew, which drips from
ceilings or down slopes.
_EnemyTips:
Faced with a Gypceros, a hunter has two
headaches to deal with: the poison and
the flashes. The poison will pool and
hamper your movements, but you can
clear it away with some watermoss. As for
the flashes, destroying its crest will stop
them; in the meantime, it's a good idea
to take cover. If you can see its crest glow
before the attack, that means you're still
inside the dazzling danger radius.

_EnemyExp: Large, pink fanged beasts. Beware their potent\r\nbreath, which changes based on their mushroom\r\ndiet, and stench, which disables recovery items.
_EnemyFeatures:
Large fanged beasts with pink fur and
a distinct crest, which the males sculpt
with plant oils and juices as a sign of virility.
Congalala are common in temperate
forests and are therefore well researched.
They're big eaters and love mushrooms,
which they absorb and then exhale as
a variety of potent breaths that inflict
poison, blast, paralysis, and more.
_EnemyTips:
The stench from a Congalala is so rancid
that healing items have no effect. But you
can quickly dispel it with a deodorant or
by evading in water. Those farts are also
trouble, but a hunter might just spot an
opportunity if they watch carefully.
Congalala are also known to use any breath
type\u{2014}a trick some have attributed to the
black mushrooms they're seen digging up.

_EnemyExp: Large, white fanged beasts that rule over other\r\nBlango, attacking as a pack. They exhibit a\r\nrange of mobility, particularly in snowy climes.
_EnemyFeatures:
Large, white fanged beasts that rule over
other Blango, attacking intruders as
a pack. Its muscularity and mobility allows
it to strike swiftly, even on fresh snow,
and pounce from long distances\u{2014}so
hunters with long-range weapons still
need to stay on guard. Large tusks are
the mark of a powerful leader.
_EnemyTips:
Blangonga use snowy ground to their
advantage for extra mobility, and can summon
other Blangos to gang up on unwary hunters.
Use extra caution when they're angry,
because they can direct the whole pack at
a chosen target with perilous efficiency.
Watch out for that freezing breath, too.
Destroying a Blangonga's tusks is believed
to undermine its authority with the other
Blangos, disrupting their teamwork.

_EnemyExp: Temnocerans that afflict poison, sleep, and\r\nwebbing ailments\u{2014}skillfully cornering prey,\r\nthen hunting it with their pincer-like jaws.
_EnemyFeatures:
Temnocerans that inhabit the Iceshard
Cliffs. They weave vast, sticky webs across
their territory, using them and various
status ailments to corner prey before
utilizing pincer-like jaws to finish it off.
Sometimes dead Gypceros can be found
in the webs, the hides of which Nerscylla
are known to adorn themselves with after
devouring the rest of the carcass.
_EnemyTips:
To defend against the poison, sleep, and
binding effects of a Nerscylla's webbing,
a hunter must go in duly prepared. While its
powerful pincers are quite dangerous, they
can and should be targeted as a weakness,
provided they are approached correctly. The
Gypceros hides draped on a Nerscylla's back
are resistant to thunder but susceptible to
fire\u{2014}qualities that are reversed once the
hide is destroyed.

_EnemyExp: Monsters draped in great wings like a black\r\novercoat. They have no eyes, so instead they\r\nuse a scattering of fine scales to locate prey.
_EnemyFeatures:
Monsters that drape themselves in their
great wings, like a black overcoat. They
have no eye sensory organs, so instead they
use a scattering of fine scales from their
wings to locate prey. When their sensory
capacity increases, antennae appear on their
heads and they unfurl their wings, entering
the aggressive Frenzy State. Their black
scales can Frenzy other creatures as well,
making them fearsome adversaries.
_EnemyTips:
Gore Magala will use its wings to attack
anything it detects with its sensory scales
without abandon. If a hunter contracts the
Frenzy, their natural healing will decrease
and any damage taken will increase, but an
experienced hunter knows to keep attacking
to raise their metabolism before the virus
takes to avoid negative effects. Target the
head to put a stop to Gore Magala's Frenzy.

_EnemyExp: Specially evolved leviathans, Mizutsune\r\ncan secrete a peculiar foam that deftly\r\ncovers their foes in dangerous bubbles.
_EnemyFeatures:
Specially evolved leviathans with sleek,
lithe bodies, Mizutsune can secrete
a peculiar foam that covers their foes
in immobilizing bubbles. Once their prey's
movement is impaired, they'll close
in with spry, dance-like movements.
_EnemyTips:
The foam of a Mizutsune allows it to move
with incredible agility even on land, but
that's not all. Different kinds of foam
produce unique effects, such as inflicting
bubbleblight, healing hunters, or boosting
your attacks. They can even employ an
explosive foam when angered. If you are
inflicted with bubbleblight, you'll be left
open for longer after taking an attack,
so fix yourself up quickly with a cleanser.

_EnemyExp: An artificial species created by an ancient\r\ncivilization with a Fulgur Anjanath\'s power. They\r\ncan discharge lightning and have a nasty bite.
_EnemyFeatures:
An artificial monster species created by an
ancient civilization and imbued with Fulgur
Anjanath's power. Guardian Fulgur Anjanath
cannot reproduce and do not require food,
relying instead on Wyvern Milk for energy.
Not only can the lightning charged in their
bodies be released as an attack, they can
also use it to empower themselves and
perform vicious biting attacks.
_EnemyTips:
A hunter must watch out for a Guardian
Fulgur Anjanath's sparks and teeth. While
their lightning attacks alone are a threat,
their maws infused with Guardian energy will
cause wide-range explosions. Try to topple
one by aggressively targeting its legs. The
crystals that form from their attacks will
explode through elemental interference,
so Slinger ammo can also be effective.

_EnemyExp: An artificial species created by an ancient\r\ncivilization with an Ebony Odogaron\'s power.\r\nThe flurries from their foreclaws pose a threat.
_EnemyFeatures:
An artificial monster species created by an
ancient civilization and imbued with Ebony
Odogaron's power. Guardian Ebony Odogaron
cannot reproduce and do not require food,
relying instead on Wyvern Milk for energy.
They will attempt to corner targets with
flurries of attacks from their well-
developed claws and tails.
_EnemyTips:
Guardian Ebony Odogaron are most notable for
their honed claws that induce bleeding and
dexterous tails, both of which carry Guardian
energy that can trigger explosions. If their
dragon-element attacks connect with
Wylkrystals, it will cause an explosion of the
same element. However, since the crystals
are triggered through elemental interference
Slinger ammo can also be used effectively.

_EnemyExp: Rugged, territorial fanged beasts that exhibit\r\nan aggressive disposition and inhabit a large\r\nrange. Sometimes observed in large packs.
_EnemyBossExp: Alpha Doshaguma are identifiable by their deeper\r\nred color and larger frame. Tread lightly\u{2014}one\r\nof them is most likely leading a pack.
_EnemyFeatures:
Fanged beasts that are sometimes seen
traveling in packs. Ruggedly built and
extremely aggressive, Doshaguma won't
hesitate to throw everything they've got at
enemies\u{2014}even other small monsters. They have
been known to take prey back to their dens,
which sometimes leads to violent disputes.
_EnemyTips:
When Doshaguma are low on health, their
wounds open exposing a weak point. They'll
grow more aggressive, though, so beware of
counterattacks. Their stomachs are exposed
when rising to their hind legs, which is a
relatively soft target and potential weak
point. Use their mobility to lure them into
rock and vine traps. If a Doshaguma pack
attacks during a separate hunt, dung pods and
large dung pods are a hunter's best friend.

_EnemyExp: An artificial species created by an ancient\r\ncivilization with a Doshaguma\'s power. They boast\r\nan incredibly robust physique and can spew acid.
_EnemyFeatures:
An artificial monster species created by
an ancient civilization and imbued with
Doshaguma's power. Guardian Doshaguma
cannot reproduce and do not require food,
relying instead on Wyvern Milk for energy.
While anything but agile, they're tough
enough to charge right through attacks
without flinching, making them extremely
dangerous.
_EnemyTips:
Most Guardian Doshaguma attacks are big
forelimb swings. While not agile, the
attacks that carry Guardian energy will
cause wide explosions. Watch out for the
acid in their saliva, which temporarily
lowers defense. By dealing with their forearm
attacks properly, you can expose a weak point
worth exploiting. The crystals formed by
their attacks will explode from elemental
interference, making Slinger ammo effective.

_EnemyExp: Desert-dwelling leviathans that use their supple,\r\nserpentine bodies to create quicksand traps. Weak\r\nagainst sonic bombs when they\'re submerged.
_EnemyFeatures:
Desert-dwelling leviathans that build
carapaces out of the fulgurite formed by
lightning strikes. They use their flexible
skeletons and serpentine bodies to create
quicksand traps for unwary prey. Inside
their mouths are multiple eye-like sensory
organs. The mucus they secrete contains
luminous bacteria and is believed to aid
visibility while they are submerged and
other low-light conditions like sandstorms.
_EnemyTips:
The interior of a Balahara's mouth is a soft
target that can be exploited if you strike
right after it expels mucus. Since they rely
on heightened hearing while submerged, sonic
bombs or screamer pods\u{2014}obtainable from
Baunos\u{2014}are highly effective. Sometimes the
large monster you're hunting will get sucked
into a Balahara sand pit...but there's
nothing stopping you from going after it.

_EnemyExp: Amphibians that affix rocks to their forelimbs\r\nto power up attacks. Break this \armor\" to create\r\nan attack opening. The tongue is most vulnerable."
_EnemyFeatures:
Amphibians that use their long tongues to seize
and devour prey such as Bulaqchi. Their evolved
forelimbs store a sticky mucus-like substance.
When agitated, Chatacabra rub their forelimbs
against the ground to collect stone and ore,
widening the range and destructiveness of their
blows.
_EnemyTips:
The Chatacabra's soft tongue is the place to
strike; look for openings after their attacks or
when they become tired. Destroying the ore
stuck to their forelimbs will leave them wide
open to attack. They roam a wide area, so
environmental elements like falling boulders
or Flashflies will be useful in taking them down.
To give you an idea of how hungry these things
can get, some hunters have witnessed them
swallowing entire barrels during their charges.

_EnemyExp: Brute wyverns that spread flammable vapor which\r\nthey then ignite with their tails. They subsist\r\non prey stolen from other predators.
_EnemyFeatures:
Brute wyverns with disproportionately long
tails. They spread a flammable substance
which vaporizes quickly, then ignite it by
dragging their tails along the ground. By
nature, Quematrice rarely hunt their own
prey, and instead scavenge herbivore
carrion left behind by other predators.
This often leads to confrontations with
other, smaller carnivores.
_EnemyTips:
Keep an eye on where flammable material
settles on the ground to gauge how much
a Quematrice's fire will spread. Since they
rely on their tails to attack from a distance
as well as to start blazes, a hunter can
weaken this monster significantly by
cutting it off.

_EnemyExp: Temnocerans native to the Scarlet Forest\r\nwith distinctive, pirouette-like movements.\r\nThe florets they release have a paralytic effect.
_EnemyFeatures:
Temnocerans native to the Scarlet Forest
with distinctive, pirouette-like movements.
Their fluids contain a neuroplegic agent
which they mix with water to produce red,
petal-like bristles on their abdomens.
When agitated, Lala Barina open these
bristles like a deadly, blossoming flower
and release them as florets that paralyze
whatever they come into contact with.
_EnemyTips:
The paralytic effects of a single Lala
Barina floret are weak and not enough to
subdue a hunter, but repeated contact should
be avoided. The stinger on their abdomens
makes approaching from the rear a risky bet,
but when tired, the stinger will stay exposed
and vulnerable. There are reports that when
in terrain such as their nests where they
hang from above, sustained attacks will
knock them down.

_EnemyExp: Dappled brute wyverns that prowl Oilwell Basin.\r\nThe gas from their tongues is toxic, and the\r\ngas in their tails can detonate the earth.
_EnemyFeatures:
Dappled brute wyverns that prowl Oilwell
Basin. They use their tails to inject gas
into the ground and detonate it, then
feed on the small creatures that are
unearthed. The toxic gas they spray from
their tongues serve to weaken prey, which
they then finish off with the blasts.
Rompopolo are extremely territorial and
will readily engage their own kind.
_EnemyTips:
Hunters must be wary of the Rompopolo's
poisonous explosions. Gas sacs can be found
all over their bodies; the anterior ones contain
poison, while the posterior sacs are for
explosions. If you see one start to swell,
strike it to shrink it back down. When
fighting in oilsilt, the blasts will kick up
rubble that can act as stable footholds.

_EnemyExp: The flying wyvern that reigns supreme over the\r\nWindward Plains\' ecosystem. It is able to store,\r\namplify, and discharge the Sandtide\'s lightning.
_EnemyFeatures:
The flying wyvern that reigns supreme over
the Windward Plains' ecosystem. It has
adapted to the Sandtide\u{2014}when it most
frequently appears\u{2014}and is able to store,
amplify, and discharge the storm's heavy
lightning to lethal effect. Rey Dau is highly
territorial and will attack any and all
intruders on sight. The fulgurite against
its carapace emits a sound that puts
every monster in the region on guard.
_EnemyTips:
When a Rey Dau's wing or tail touches the
ground while charged, it causes a reaction
that produces a mantle of fulgurite. This
widens the appendage's attack range and
increases the monster's charging capacity\u{2014}
so make it a point to break these parts.
Their heads may also be vulnerable after
a discharge attack. Hunters are advised
to bring thunder-resistant armor and
ice-based weaponry.

_EnemyExp: The leviathan that reigns supreme over the\r\nScarlet Forest\'s ecosystem. Its protective veil\r\ncan also generate a wave to keep foes at bay.
_EnemyFeatures:
The leviathan that reigns supreme over the
Scarlet Forest's ecosystem. It has adapted
to water-rich environments and is sighted
most often during the Downpour. Uth Duna's
secretions when combined with water form
a protective veil that not only absorbs
hostile blows but also adds weight, which it
slams down with enough force to sweep away
surrounding threats in the resulting wave.
_EnemyTips:
Seeing as an Uth Duna's veil reduces attack
damage, the first order of business is to
dispel it quickly. It will fall away once it
loses enough water, but that's not entirely
good news; without the veil weighing the
monster down, an Uth Duna will become more
agile and aggressive. You can dodge their
wave with some creative evading, or by using
things like Wedge Beetles to escape upward.

_EnemyExp: The cephalopod that reigns supreme over\r\nOilwell Basin\'s ecosystem. A vision of hell,\r\nit attacks with tentacles and ignited oilsilt.
_EnemyFeatures:
The cephalopod that reigns supreme over
Oilwell Basin's ecosystem. Usually, when
sighted, Nu Udra is covered in oilsilt, but
when enraged it will ignite the coating,
transfiguring itself into a horror of flame.
The oculi that appear on its body and many
arms are presumed to be sensory organs,
but the truth is still being investigated.
_EnemyTips:
Each of a Nu Udra's many unique tentacles
can be severed. But watch out when they get
angry and burst into flame. You can douse
any parts that are burning with watermoss\u{2014}
a recommended strategy, since it will
leave the monster weakened. A Nu Udra's soft
body allows them to slip through crevasses
and move in surprising ways, so be careful
not to let them get the jump on you.

_EnemyExp: Fanged beasts that adhere metal to their bodies\r\nand use friction to heat and cause explosions.\r\nThey move in groups during the Firespring.
_EnemyFeatures:
Characteristic by their highly developed
carapaces, Ajarakan wrap themselves in
molten metal that they rub together to heat
up and create explosions. Presumably due
to the friction of the metal, they can reach
high enough temperatures to melt even the
ground or bullets. They can also use their
strong limbs to grip onto the ceiling and
move around freely, so a hunter must watch
out from every angle, including above.
_EnemyTips:
Approaching an Ajarakan's extreme heat
will sap your health, so use cool drinks
or Chillmantle Bugs to counteract it. Normal
Ammo and arrows will melt if you try to
pierce their molten carapaces, so you must
use heat-resistant equipment or hit them with
Watermoss to bring down their temperature
first. Continuous friction will cause their
body temperature to rise, but soften their
outer shells.

_EnemyExp: A wyvern with chain-like wings. The flexible\r\nchainblades on their wings are used to mow\r\ndown prey and absorb elemental energy.
_EnemyFeatures:
A flying wyvern that was considered extinct
according to documents left behind by the
Guild. Their wings have a unique, chain-like
blade that can extend and retract freely to
reap their prey. They feed on elemental energy
absorbed through these chainblades, and are
able to convert the energy to unleash dragon
element attacks.
_EnemyTips:
The more energy this monster absorbs, the
more ferocious its attacks become. Once they
fill their energy tanks, their chainblades
will sweep out to attack an even wider area.
Conversely, since their wings possess organs
that absorb energy, a hunter can force the
energy to leak out by focusing attacks there.
Flooding them with continuous elemental
attacks will eventually overload the organs,
forcing the monster out of its enhanced state.

_EnemyExp: An artificial species created by an ancient\r\ncivilization based on a presumed extinct,\r\nlegendary monster called Arkveld.
_EnemyFeatures:
An artificial species created by an ancient
civilization and imbued with the power of
a monster called Arkveld. It cannot reproduce
and does not require food, relying instead
on Wyvern Milk for energy. In addition to
absorbing and discharging energy the way
other Guardians do, Guardian Arkveld can
also absorb elemental energy through the
chainblades on its wings and use it for
sustenance.
_EnemyTips:
Guardian Arkveld use retractable chainblades
on their wings to attack. Not only are the
blades used to absorb and release energy like
other Guardians, but they can also convert
the energy to the dragon element and
discharge it, which will trigger an explosion
of the same element if it comes into contact
with Wylkrystals. The crystals formed by
their attacks will explode from elemental
interference, making Slinger ammo effective.

_EnemyExp: Leviathans that inhabit the Iceshard Cliffs. They\r\nhave sharp, pincer-like tails and membranes on\r\ntheir necks that catch the wind to keep them aloft.
_EnemyFeatures:
Leviathans that inhabit the Iceshard Cliffs.
They have sharp, pincer-like tails and
peculiar membranes on their necks that
catch the wind and keep them aloft.
Hirabami can sometimes be sighted nesting
in groups along the cliffs, using their
scales or foreclaws to cling to walls or
ceilings while they sleep.
_EnemyTips:
Hirabami can remain aloft as they maneuver
skillfully between the ground and the sky.
You'll need to watch out for those tail
claws, but handle an attack well to turn it
into a counterstrike opportunity. Destroying
the membrane on their necks will lower their
guards while aloft. Furthermore, you can
target the membrane wound to knock them out
of the air, making this a prime target.

_EnemyExp: A leviathan that sits at the peak of the\r\nIceshard Cliffs\' ecosystem. It generates cold\r\nair via cooling organs across its massive body.
_EnemyFeatures:
A leviathan that sits at the peak of the
Iceshard Cliffs' ecosystem. It surrounds
its massive form in cold temperatures
via ridge-like cooling organs across its
body; the frost its limbs produce
doubles as a potent weapon and a way
to travel along walls and floating rocks.
_EnemyTips:
Every part of Jin Dahaad's massive
body is capable of powerful freezing
attacks. Diminish their offensive
capabilities by attacking the ridges
that they use for cooling. The largest
ridges on their back are particularly
powerful and should be destroyed, but
the hide there is very tough unless
the other ridges are dealt with first.

_EnemyExp: Cephalopods that roam the Ruins of Wyveria and\r\nprey on Guardians. This often leads to conflicts\r\nbetween the two monsters.
_EnemyFeatures:
Cephalopod predators whose prey include
Guardian monsters. The mucus secreted from
their tentacles hardens quickly into sharp edges
that resemble blades or spears, which is why
some call Xu Wu the \Piercing Assassin." The
sizable mouth hidden on their underside allows
them to devour even rather large prey."
_EnemyTips:
Due to their predatory nature, you can
expect Xu Wu to attack Guardians inside
their habitat. They have no eyes, but their
other senses are developed and they excel at
catching prey off guard, especially with
their ability to enter small crevices and
crawl quickly across the ground. When one
exposes its mouth, that means a deadly
attack is coming, but with a powerful blow,
you might be able to topple the creature.

_EnemyExp: A Guardian created to be Wyveria\'s savior.\r\nIt was feeding off the Dragontorch, drawing from\r\nthe vast stores of energy while it slumbered.
_EnemyFeatures:
A massive Guardian that has been feeding
off the Dragontorch's energy. Its body
is encased in crystallized Wyvern Milk,
allowing it to regenerate. Zoh Shia, like
other Guardians, excels at energy attacks
and can produce repeated explosions to
crystallize the whole area. Beneath its
white Guardian coat, its body pulses with
dark recollection\u{2014}which you may see, should
it reveal its full power from the days of yore.
_EnemyTips:
Zoh Shia share the same basic traits of
other Guardians. The crystals on their wings
and heads can be stripped away to deplete
their energy stores. The white crystals on
their bodies will grow back weaker, making
them easier to destroy a second time. The
crystals they create will detonate if they
take elemental damage, but a talented hunter
can use elemental Slinger ammo and smart
maneuvering to make good use of them.

_EnemyExp: <COLOR FF0000>#Rejected#</COLOR> EnemyText_EXP_EM0165_00_0
Neopterons with paralyzing poison stingers. They\r\nare quite fragile, so carefully take them down with\r\nyour Slinger or poison to safely carve materials.
_EnemyFeatures:
Neopterons with paralyzing poison stingers
on their abdomens. Since Vespoids are
attracted to light, hunters can use
brightmoss to mark large monsters, which
Vespoid will then attack and paralyze.
To finish off a Vespoid without damaging
its delicate materials, a hunter must avoid
blunt trauma and use attacks that gradually
drain its health. Vespoid fluids are useful
for crafting with monster bones.

_EnemyExp: Fanged beasts with pink fur that prefer mild,\r\ndamp climates. Generally, they don\'t form large\r\npacks and only live together in small numbers.
_EnemyFeatures:
Fanged beasts with pink fur. Packs typically
consist of females and juveniles. An adult
male Congalala may occasionally be sighted
within a pack, but these are non-social
creatures that don't establish a chain of
command. Beware their terrific flatulence,
as they will use it to inflict stench on
perceived threats.

_EnemyExp: Fanged beasts with snow-white pelts. Blango\r\ntravel in packs with a Blangonga at the head,\r\nworking together to eliminate intruders.
_EnemyFeatures:
Fanged beasts with snow-white pelts.
Blango generally travel in groups with
a Blangonga leading them. As a pack, they
work together efficiently to eliminate
threats to their territory, responding
instantly to their leader's commands.

_EnemyExp: Male Ceratonoth. They use their large spikes\r\nto disperse lightning into the ground and\r\nprotect the females of their sizeable herds.
_EnemyFeatures:
Male Ceratonoth, known for their large
herds. During sandstorms, they use their
large spikes to channel any lightning
strikes. This process sometimes causes
fulgurite to form on parts of their bodies.
A male responds quickly when a large
predator attacks and makes an effort to
lead his herd to safety.

_EnemyExp: Female Ceratonoth. In a harsh climate where\r\nnourishment is difficult to come by, they\r\nare frequently targeted by predators.
_EnemyBossExp: Ceratonoth juveniles are treasured by their\r\nherds. Due to their arrival during the Plenty,\r\nthe people of Kunafa view them as a good omen.

_EnemyExp: Herbivores that move between habitats in response\r\nto environmental changes. When in danger, they\r\nuse their head plating to fight back.
_EnemyBossExp: Juvenile Dalthydon. Their cranial plating\r\nhasn\'t fully hardened yet, and their pelts are\r\na neutral color to avoid drawing attention.
_EnemyFeatures:
Herbivores that live in herds and move
between habitats in response to environmental
changes. Dalthydon are bred as livestock
and play an important role in human life.
Although they are docile in general, when
the herd is in danger, they assume a group
defensive formation and use their evolved
cranial plating as a weapon.

_EnemyExp: Herbivores that are raised as livestock.\r\nIn addition to providing wool and milk, they\r\nare also used for physical labor.
_EnemyBossExp: Juvenile Dalthydon. Their cranial plating\r\nhasn\'t fully hardened yet, and their pelts are\r\na neutral color to avoid drawing attention.

_EnemyExp: Neopterons that use swarming tactics to contain\r\nand subdue prey, then dissolve it from the inside.\r\nSonic bombs will disable their sensory organs.
_EnemyFeatures:
Neopterons that inhabit the Windward Plains.
They use their needle-like mouths to pour
digestive juices into carrion to dissolve it
into easily consumed fluids. Feeding makes
them bloated and sluggish, so they have to
rest on walls or ceilings. Their forelegs
double as sensory organs that they use to
assess their surroundings, but they are
quite sensitive, so a loud noise is usually
enough to immobilize a Bulaqchi.

_EnemyExp: Carnivores that work together to attack\r\nintruders using their powerful jaws. A clever\r\nhunter can turn them against larger monsters.
_EnemyFeatures:
Carnivores that prowl the Windward Plains.
Their distinct jaw is designed to grab
prey and not let go, and they excel at
working together to hunt and deal with
intruders. It's not uncommon to see a pack
of Talioth take on a bigger monster and
win by sheer numbers; a clever hunter will
take advantage of this and use Talioth to
distract or weaken their main target.

_EnemyExp: Winged wyverns that vibrate their thoraxes\r\nto create a deafening roar. You can nab screamer\r\npods from them using the Hook Slinger.
_EnemyFeatures:
Winged wyverns that inhabit the Windward
Plains. Rather than do their own hunting,
they use their high vantage to scavenge
carrion. Baunos take shelter to avoid the
lightning during an Inclemency. When
a little intimidation is called for, they
vibrate their thorax feathers to create
a deafening roar. You can get screamer pods
from them with the Hook Slinger.

_EnemyExp: Leviathans with distinct snouts that live near\r\nwater. Obtain bleeding pods by firing your Hook\r\nSlinger at them.
_EnemyFeatures:
Leviathans with distinct snouts that live
near water. If the water is deep enough, a
Gajios will stay submerged with only the tip
of its nose exposed, waiting for prey to
wander by. You can obtain bleeding pods with
the Hook Slinger\u{2014}but not without a fight.

_EnemyExp: Leviathans with beautiful scales and blade-like\r\nprotrusions. They primarily inhabit the Scarlet\r\nForest, and hunt in highly organized packs.
_EnemyFeatures:
Leviathans whose bodies are covered with
beautiful scales and sharp blades. As a pack,
they work together to surround prey, but
since most Piragill are too timid to make
the kill, they usually wait for an opening
and lunge all at once. Don't underestimate
them; on water, their speed is unmatched,
and those blades will make mincemeat of a
hunter that wanders too close.

_EnemyExp: Winged wyverns that are identifiable by the\r\nlong, sharp horn on their heads. Obtain piercing\r\npods by firing the Hook Slinger at them.
_EnemyFeatures:
Winged wyverns that are identifiable by the
long, sharp horn on their heads\u{2014}which just
so happen to make great Slinger ammo.
Large as the Harpios may be, they never
attack hunters, choosing instead to stay by
the water and prey on fish. On occasions
when large fish scare the smaller ones to
the surface, you might even get to see a
bona fide Harpios feeding frenzy.

_EnemyExp: Small carnivores that prowl Oilwell Basin,\r\nhunting in small packs. They have been known\r\nto engage larger monsters while feeding.
_EnemyFeatures:
Carnivores that prowl Oilwell Basin. Their
skulls have evolved in a way that lets them
expand and contract the plating, and lunge
at prey with hammer-like blows. They hunt
Gelidron and keep their packs small. There
have been accounts of Kranodath engaging
larger monsters while feeding, where they
cling to the enemy's skull and stun it with
repeated head bashes.

_EnemyExp: Neopterons with well-developed tail stingers\r\nand forelegs. They surround prey in colonies,\r\nusing their tails to inject a sleeping agent.
_EnemyFeatures:
Neopterons that inhabit the Iceshard
Cliffs. Comaqchi rarely move around,
staying adhered to the walls most of
the time in large colonies. Their forelegs
are well adapted to striking, and they
can use their well-developed tail
stingers to inject a sleeping agent that
make targets easier to prey upon.

_EnemyExp: Amphibians that have adapted to their dry, hot\r\nhabitat by producing a protective slime. Their\r\ntasty flesh makes them a target of carnivores.
_EnemyFeatures:
Amphibians commonly found in Oilwell Basin.
Subcutaneous slime protects them from
getting burned. Gelidron lay ambushes,
waiting to snap up prey with their big,
meaty tongues. Fine hairs on their digits,
combined with sharp claws, allow them to
climb straight up walls. Unfortunately for
the Gelidron, their edible parts are
delicious, putting them in high demand with
carnivores in the wild...as well as in Azuz.

_EnemyExp: Herbivores that live in herds in cold areas.\r\nThey are targeted by predators as a source of\r\nsustenance where flora and fauna are scarce.
_EnemyBossExp: Herbivores that live primarily in cold regions.\r\nThe larger alphas protect the herd, and can be\r\nharvested for paralytic Slinger ammo.
_EnemyFeatures:
Herbivores that live primarily in cold
regions. Rafma form herds with a large alpha
at the head. When threatened, the alpha
discharges static energy stored in its horn
to shock foes and defend the herd. This horn
can also be targeted with the Hook Slinger
to get paralytic ammo. Rafma have been
sighted moving along dizzyingly steep
cliffsides, to the wonderment of observers.

_EnemyExp: Bird wyverns with sharp bristles on their heads.\r\nObtain Slinger ammo that is effective at creating\r\nwounds by firing your Hook Slinger at them.
_EnemyFeatures:
Bird wyverns that live in herds at the heart
of the Ruins of Wyveria. Porkeplumes are
extremely timid and will protect themselves
against threats by puffing out the bristles
on their heads. If the situation escalates,
a member of the herd will slam into the foe
with its bristles, giving the other members
a window to escape. The head bristles can be
used as bleeding pods for the Slinger.

_EnemyExp: Newly-hatched Nerscylla larvae. They form colonies\r\nin the bodies of devoured prey, nests, and other\r\nhidey-holes, and react as a group when provoked.
_EnemyFeatures:
The larval form of a temnoceran that
inhabits the Iceshard Cliffs. At this stage,
they cannot use webbing or status ailments
like adult Nerscylla, but these little fellows
like to gang up, surround prey, and then
pounce all at once.

_EnemyExp: Artificial wyverns created by an ancient\r\ncivilization. They hatch from small cocoons and\r\ntravel in packs, attacking with sharp claws.
_EnemyFeatures:
Artificial wyverns created by an ancient
civilization. They dash through the Ruins
of Wyveria in search of Wyvern Milk, their
source of energy. Unlike the original
Seikret, the Guardian types are aggressive
and have sharp, dangerous claws on their
unique forelegs. They generally travel in
packs of two or three, but if threatened,
they may call for more help and try to
surround the adversary.

_EnemyExp: Toads containing a paralytic gas. Hitting them\r\nwill release the gas, which is powerful enough\r\nto stop large monsters in their tracks.
_FirstCapture: Toads that contain a powerful, paralytic gas\r\nwhich they can use as a defensive measure\r\nto stop threats in their tracks.
_Memo:
Toads containing a paralytic gas that are
usually found by the water. They are
sensitive to force and will release the
gas as a defensive measure; it's powerful
enough to stop hunters and large monsters in
their tracks, which buys the Paratoad time
to escape. Hunters can use this behavior to
direct the gas at a desired target and gain
the upper hand.

_EnemyExp: When struck, Nitrotoads release a spray\r\nof volatile liquid that detonates with enough\r\npower to stagger even large monsters.
_FirstCapture: A toad that stores an explosive liquid within\r\nits body. The explosions it produces are so\r\nstrong they even make larger monsters flinch.
_Memo:
Toads that store an explosive liquid within
their bodies. Any physical stimulus causes
them to spray this liquid and flee. Once
the liquid contacts the air, it detonates,
wreaking havoc. Though these creatures
prefer to live in environments abounding in
combustible materials like coal, their diet
actually consists mostly of insects and
crustaceans. It is yet unknown what causes
them to produce the explosive liquid.

_EnemyExp: Toads that store sleeping gas in their bodies.\r\nA shock will cause them to spray the gas, which\r\nis potent enough to affect monsters.
_FirstCapture: Toads that store a potent gas in their\r\nbodies that can put monsters to sleep.
_Memo:
Toads that store sleeping gas in their
bodies. A shock will cause them to spray the
gas, putting the enemy to sleep while they
escape. The gas is so potent that it affects
hunters and even large monsters. You may
be able to gain the upper hand if you use
this to your advantage and direct the gas
at a monster.

_EnemyExp: Insects that carry restorative nectar.\r\nA light impact causes the nectar to scatter,\r\nproducing a continual healing effect.
_FirstCapture: Insects that gather restorative nectar from\r\nVitalilies and store it, with more or less\r\nthe same properties, in their abdomens.
_Memo:
Insects that gather restorative nectar from
Vitalilies and store it in their abdomens.
While the flowers and nectar have similar
properties, the latter can be scattered in
large quantities to produce a lingering,
continual healing effect. There's a rise
in the Vigorwasp population during
the Plenty, when Vitalilies flourish.

_EnemyExp: Large wasps that carry more nectar at a higher\r\nconcentration. A light impact scatters the\r\nnectar, producing a continual healing effect.
_FirstCapture: Large wasps that carry more nectar at\r\na higher concentration. Frequently seen\r\nduring the Plenty.
_Memo:
Large wasps that carry more nectar at a
higher concentration. This boosts the range
and potency of the nectar's restorative
effects. They are most prevalent during the
Plenty, when the Vigorwasps have learned
the nectar will be more plentiful. They are
sometimes sighted in groups.

_EnemyExp: Insects that store nectar. An impact will cause\r\nthem to release it, providing immediate health\r\nrecovery and relief from status ailments.
_FirstCapture: Insects that store nectar in their abdomens\r\nwith restorative, detoxifying, and\r\ndeodorizing properties.
_Memo:
Insects that store nectar in their
abdomens with restorative, detoxifying,
and deodorizing properties. Since the
effects are different from a Vigorwasp's,
it is believed that this species collects
ingredients from medicinal plants other
than Vitalilies. However, based on ongoing
research, it has been found that enzymes
in their bodies could also play a role.

_EnemyExp: Insects that flash when struck. The larger their\r\ncolony, the brighter they shine. They can be\r\nused to blind large monsters.
_FirstCapture: Insects that flash when struck. Alone, their\r\nlight is faint, but in colonies they shine\r\nmore intensely.
_Memo:
Insects that flash when struck. Usually,
they live solitary existences with too faint
a flicker to even notice. In caves or the
dark of night, they form colonies where
their light is more intense; striking them
causes them to shine even brighter. On hunts,
they can be used like flash bombs to blind
and disorient monsters.

_EnemyExp: Insects that habitually roll up monster dung.\r\nThe dung pods are well compacted and can\r\nbe used as Slinger ammo.
_FirstCapture: Insects that habitually roll up monster dung:\r\nnature\'s diligent decomposers. The dung pods\r\ncan be used as Slinger ammo.
_Memo:
Insects that habitually roll up monster
dung. They bring it back to their
underground nests not just for food, but to
lay eggs on and feed their larvae. They're
the faces of feces across the land: nature's
diligent decomposers. The compacted dung
pods formed by their efforts can be used as
Slinger ammo. It's foul enough to send even
large monsters running for fresh air\u{2014}a
useful trick when you're outnumbered.

_EnemyExp: An insect that rolls explosive rocks and\r\nbrings them back to its nest. These rocks\r\ncan be used as Slinger ammo.
_FirstCapture: An insect that rolls explosive rocks and\r\nbrings them back to its nest. These rocks\r\ncan be used as Slinger ammo.
_Memo:
Beetles that roll around explosive rocks.
Because both these rocks and their habitat
are extremely hot, their bodies have evolved
to withstand heat. It's yet unclear what
they do with the rocks once they get back to
their nests, but some theorize that they are
fed to the beetles' young.

_EnemyExp: Beetles that gather up snowballs and roll them\r\nback to their nests. The snowballs can be used\r\nas Slinger frostburst ammo.
_FirstCapture: Insects that roll balls of snow until they\r\nharden. These ice balls can be used as\r\nSlinger ammo.
_Memo:
Beetles that gather up snow. Their snowballs
can be used as Frostburst Ammo. Due to their
ecology, Icebeetles are limited to cold
habitats and are more tolerant of cold than
other insects. No one knows why they roll
their snowballs back to their nests. Some
theorize it's to grow the organic matter
they feed on, while others think it could be
related to reproductive behavior.

_EnemyExp: Insects that wear healing herbs like cloaks,\r\nproducing a restorative nectar that can be\r\ncollected from them using the Hook Slinger.
_FirstCapture: Insects that wear healing herbs like cloaks.\r\nThe cloak serves a double purpose: to store\r\nnutrients and to defend against predators.
_Memo:
Insects that wear healing herbs like
cloaks, initiating a fermentation process
that creates a nectar with similar
restorative properties. Collecting the
cloak by hand or with the Hook Slinger
will restore health. The cloak stores
nutrients but can be shed in a pinch as
a distraction to defend against predators.

_EnemyExp: Insects that hoard honey with heat-relieving\r\nproperties in the casing on their backs. They\r\nferment plants with cooling components.
_FirstCapture: An insect that wraps itself in a case of\r\nplant matter. The case has a mucus that\r\nprotects it from high temperatures.
_Memo:
Insects that live in extremely hot
environments. They wrap themselves in a
case of plant matter\u{2014}much like their mantle
bug brethren\u{2014}but the plants they use have
cooling properties, allowing them to
withstand heat. They are able to survive
without the casing by burrowing
underground.

_EnemyExp: Insects that hoard honey with cold-relieving\r\nproperties in the casing on their backs. They\r\nferment plants with heating components.
_FirstCapture: An insect that wraps itself in a case of\r\nplant matter. The case has a mucus that\r\nprotects it from low temperatures.
_Memo:
Insects that live in extremely cold
environments. They wrap themselves in
plant matter\u{2014}much like their mantle bug
brethren\u{2014}but they use plants with heating
properties, such as hot peppers, to
mitigate the cold. They can live on the
surface thanks to this, but if uncloaked
they must burrow underground to survive.

_EnemyExp: Insects that thrive in rotting wood and soil.\r\nHighly nutritious, they can be consumed to\r\nincrease stamina and halve its depletion rate.
_FirstCapture: Insects that thrive in rotting wood and soil.\r\nEven monsters consume them because of their\r\nhigh nutritional value.
_Memo:
Insects that thrive in rotting wood and
soil due to their diet of plants and
rotting leaves. Consuming them will
increase stamina and halve its depletion
rate. Their high nutritional value makes
them a common snack for some monsters.

_EnemyExp: Nocturnal hornets that use a luminous organ to\r\nwarn foes before attacking with their stingers\u{2014}\r\neven large monsters aren\'t safe.
_FirstCapture: Nocturnal, territorial hornets that use a\r\nluminous organ to light up targets before\r\nattacking with poison stingers.
_Memo:
Nocturnal hornets with strong defensive
instincts. When they sense danger, they
use a luminous organ to illuminate the
area to check for threats, if one is spotted,
they attack relentlessly with their poisonous
stingers. Unlike other endemic life, Dark
Hornets will readily attack large monsters
that disturb their nests. Their diet also
doesn't stimulate honey production, so
hunters are better off steering clear.

_EnemyExp: A colony of Thunderbugs galvanized by\r\nsandstorm lightning. A population this dense\r\ncan stop even large monsters in their tracks.
_FirstCapture: A large colony of Thunderbugs that have been\r\nvitalized by the sandstorm\'s lightning,\r\nresulting in a dense population.
_Memo:
A large colony of Thunderbugs that
reproduced rapidly as a result of the
sandstorm lightning. A population this dense
can produce enough current to stop even
large monsters in their tracks. Since
Thunderbugs are the fuel behind shock traps,
there's merit to trying to lead large
monsters into the colony as a way to
gain the upper hand.

_EnemyExp: Insects that cling firmly to walls and other\r\nsurfaces. Latching on to them with the Slinger\r\ncan help you traverse terrain and evade attacks.
_FirstCapture: Insects with robust shells that can\r\nwithstand lesser impacts. They make great\r\nlatching points for the Slinger.
_Memo:
Insects with robust shells that can
withstand most lesser impacts. They cling
firmly to walls and other surfaces, making
them excellent latching points for the
Slinger, whether it's to get around or
simply to hang out indefinitely. However,
a Wedge Beetle in flight can only bear
the weight for a limited time, so it's best
to latch on briefly to gain some height.

_EnemyExp: Insects that store electricity. Found near\r\nelectrical sources, they can be used to make\r\ntools like shock traps and Thunder Ammo.
_FirstCapture: Insects capable of discharging small amounts\r\nof electricity. They are drawn to electrical\r\nsources, which enhance them on contact.
_Memo:
Insects capable of discharging small amounts
of electricity. They are drawn to electrical
sources, particularly the fulgurite formed
by lightning strikes. Thunderbug materials
can be used to craft many useful tools such
as shock traps and Thunder Ammo.

_EnemyExp: Insects with apparatuses capable of\r\nproducing strong bursts of light. Their\r\nmaterials are used in Slinger flash pods.
_FirstCapture: Insects that emit strong, involuntary bursts\r\nof light in response to external factors.
_Memo:
Insects that emit strong bursts of light in
response to external factors. It was long
believed that blunt trauma or death were the
triggers, but this theory has been rejected.
It is now thought that some constituent
element of their body fluid vaporizes and
produces the flash. In any case, their
materials are highly prized for their utility
in items like Slinger flash pods.

_EnemyExp: Insects said to live for a thousand years. Their\r\nextracts can be combined with other items to\r\ncreate powders with their supportive properties.
_FirstCapture: Insects that live a very long time\u{2014}\r\na thousand years, by some accounts, although\r\nno such specimens have been discovered.
_Memo:
Insects that are claimed by some tomes and
oral histories to live for a thousand years.
No such specimens have been discovered, but
studies of the Godbug's tissue prove that
they do enjoy significant longevity. Their
body fluids have diffusive properties that
can be combined with other items to create
powders with the same attributes.

_EnemyExp: Insects whose bitter extracts promote\r\nnatural healing and can be combined into\r\na variety of useful medicines and items.
_FirstCapture: Insects whose bitter extracts promote\r\nnatural healing, disinfect wounds, and more,\r\nmaking them a valuable material.
_Memo:
Insects whose bitter extracts are used
for a wide variety of medicinal purposes.
In addition to promoting natural healing,
disinfecting, and mitigating poisons,
they also boost the efficacy of other
medicines, making them highly useful.
That said, by themselves they have little
effect and taste extremely bitter, so
it's best to consider them an ingredient,
not a solution in their own right.

_EnemyExp: Forest ants that form ranks and carry\r\nleaves with medicinal properties, which\r\ncan be collected to make healing items.
_FirstCapture: An ant that gathers leaves in droves. The\r\nleaves are brought to its nest and used to\r\ncultivate the fungi it eats.
_Memo:
Forest ants known for forming ranks and
carrying leaves. Their sharp mandibles
consist of a sharp edge for cutting and a
separate apparatus for bending the leaves
back behind their heads for easy carrying.
Leaflugger Ants use these leaves as
substrates to grow fungi, their primary
sustenance. As it turns out, the leaves also
have medicinal properties, making them
useful to hunters.

_EnemyExp: Herding monsters that mostly inhabit the savannah.\r\nThey use their distinctive arrow-shaped crests to communicate\r\nand warn other members of their herd of danger.
_FirstCapture: Small, common plains dwellers with\r\narrow-like crests they use to coordinate\r\nwith others in their pack.
_Memo:
Plains dwellers that move in packs. They
use their arrow-like crests to coordinate
movements and alert each other to threats.
Since they stand their crests up when people
and monsters draw near, that gesture is
believed to indicate danger. Windrustlers
have been sighted in Kunafa, a sign that
they have learned two things: people aren't
always a threat...and where there's people,
there's food.

_FirstCapture: A rare variant occasionally spotted in a\r\nWindrustler pack. Distinguishable by their\r\ncharcoal skin and larger frame.
_Memo:
A rare variant occasionally spotted in
a Windrustler pack, with charcoal skin and
a larger frame. While it could be a type of
melanistic mutation, there are enough unique
examples to suggest this might even be
a subspecies. Their role in the pack and
relationship with others of their kind are
important topics that warrant further study.

_FirstCapture: Birds that live in symbiosis with the\r\nCeratonoth. They pick away old scales\r\nand feed on insects in between the cracks.
_Memo:
Birds that live in symbiosis with the
Ceratonoths and are often seen perched on
their backs. They use their plier-like beaks
to pick away old scales and feed on insects
that have wormed their way into the cracks.
In return for this grooming service, the
Ceratonoths give the Nothpeckers a place
to feed and shelter from outside threats\u{2014}
a win-win situation for all creatures
involved.

_EnemyExp: A decomposer that breaks down the Fulgurite\r\nin its body consumed in order to eat the attached\r\nmicrobes. The Fulgurite makes its carapace shine.
_FirstCapture: Crustaceans that use their secretions to\r\nbreak down fulgurite and feed on the\r\norganic matter and microbes found within.
_Memo:
Shrimp-like creatures that use their
secretions to comb through fulgurite and
feed on organic matter like dead Thunderbugs.
The consumption of some of these microbes
seems to have given the Landlight Shrimp a
kind of luminescence. They use hook-like
appendages to cling to rock faces in large
numbers, happily eating away at the fulgurite
and occasionally triggering falling boulders.

_FirstCapture: A land-dwelling crustacean that gathers on\r\ngaseous vents. Comes in a variety of sizes.
_Memo:
Land-dwelling crustaceans that gather on
gaseous vents in the Oilwell Basin. The hair
on their heads and chests collects particles
from the gas and steam, which attract the
microbes that they feed on. The faint light
they produce is thought to be a byproduct of
the microbes they eat. They appear in a
variety of sizes during the Firespring.

_EnemyExp: A migratory bird that flocks to the savannah during\r\nthe bounty season to raise its young. It makes its nest\r\nlargely from the bubbles it produces internally.
_FirstCapture: Migrant birds that live in the forest, but\r\ntravel to the plains during the Plenty.\r\nKnown for their foam nests and birdsong.
_Memo:
Migrant birds that live in the forest, but
travel to the plains during the Plenty
to raise their young. Amstrigians choose
lifelong mates and share the work when it
comes to gathering food, building nests, and
minding their young. Their meal of choice
is insects, particularly Emperor Hoppers.
They use their syrinxes to sing in chorus at
the turning of the season, a social ritual
that doubles as a form of communication.

_FirstCapture: A bird with a beautiful voice. It\'s very\r\nsimilar to the Amstrigian and can be seen\r\nmixed in with their flocks.
_Memo:
Rare birds with beautiful voices. Though
similar to the Amstrigian, their stunning
songs and colorful feathers distinguish
them. Not much is known about them due
to their rarity.

_EnemyExp: A lizard that stores nutrients in a handkerchief-like\r\nsac. During the bounty season, it becomes predatorily\r\nactive and its body takes on a red color.
_FirstCapture: Plateau-dwelling lizards with adipose\r\ntissue near their jaws that differ\r\ndepending on their nutritional intake.
_Memo:
Lizards with adipose tissue near their
jaws and tail. When food is plentiful, these
sac-like reservoirs fatten up and turn a
healthy red. A Rufflizard with plenty of
food in the tank is a happy Rufflizard, and
you may see them basking in the sun and
bobbing to each other in greeting. A poorly
fed Rufflizard however, will move as
little as possible.

_FirstCapture: A lizard with a distinctive crease on\r\nits head. It loves hot environments\r\nand is often seen in volcanic areas.
_Memo:
Lizards with distinctive creases on their
heads. When they bob their heads to
communicate, the crease opens and glows
along with the pattern on their bodies. They
prefer hot environments such as volcanic
areas. Though rarely seen in the oilsilt-
filled upper areas of the Oilwell Basin,
they become far more active during the
Firespring. It's theorized that they primarily
feed on bugs that lurk among the rocks.

_FirstCapture: An Ember Rufflizard peculiarly clad in blue\r\nand yellow.
_Memo:
Rare lizards with a different coloration
than the more common Ember Rufflizard.
Since they so closely resemble the common
Ember Rufflizard in every other way, they are
currently thought to be a mere color variant
as opposed to a subspecies. However, many
reports claim these lizards are far larger,
so they may be in the process of evolving
into their own subspecies, a current hot
topic among researchers.

_EnemyExp: A decomposer that eats dead monster carcasses.\r\nIt holds food with its hair-covered ambulatory legs.
_FirstCapture: Insects that gather on carrion and feed on\r\nthe dead flesh. Their foreleg bristles help\r\nthem sweep food into their mouths.
_Memo:
Insects that feed on dead flesh and serve
as decomposers in the ecosystem. They use
the bristles on their forelegs and joints to
sweep organic matter from the carrion.
When they're not feeding on dead monsters,
they can usually be found lurking in between
rocks or other places the sun doesn't reach.

_EnemyExp: An animal distinctive for the monogamous pairing\r\nit forms with another individual of its species. It can\r\nuse its large tail to stand itself up and warn others.
_FirstCapture: Creatures with unusual tails that are native\r\nto the sands. They typically travel in pairs.
_Memo:
Endemic creatures that are native to the
Windward Plains\u{2014}particularly its deserts.
Thanks to their unusual tails, they can
sit upright and assess their surroundings,
or they can shield themselves from the hot
sun. When they sit, their tails leave a
mark in the sand that resembles a large
monster's footprint. They typically travel
in pairs to watch each other's back while
doing things like drinking.

_EnemyExp: A grasshopper as big as its moniker\r\nwould suggest. Its swift, frenetic\r\njumps make it hard to capture.
_FirstCapture: Huge grasshoppers worthy of their name.\r\nTheir powerful hind legs allow them to jump\r\naway, making them difficult to catch.
_Memo:
Huge grasshoppers that have fully
earned their name. Their powerful hind
legs allow them to jump long distances
and escape in a pinch. If you rustle
through the grass\u{2014}their usual hiding
spot\u{2014}you're bound to see at least one
Emperor Hopper spring away. Grass fires
throw them into a panic, a situation
that certain other hungry creatures
might be eager to take advantage of.

_FirstCapture: A puzzling phase mutation of the Emperor\r\nHopper. Their bodies have a reddish-black\r\ndiscoloration, and are way more ferocious.
_Memo:
A phase mutation of the Emperor Hopper.
Their bodies are reddish-black and are more
ferocious. While Hoppers are usually
herbivorous, this type feeds on carrion. Due
to similarities across different regions, it
is believed the mutation must occur in
environments where plants are scarce. This
causal relationship between a creature's
formative environment and its mutations has
become a major subject of research.

_EnemyExp: A large beetle with impressive horns.\r\nHercudrome only inhabit seven\r\nspecific spots in the Windward Plains.
_FirstCapture: Beetles with distinct horns extending from the\r\nhead and pronotum. They feed mainly on sap,\r\nand can often be found resting on tree trunks.
_Memo:
Beetles with distinct horns extending from
the head and pronotum. They are nocturnal
and feed mainly on sap, which you can see if
you observe tree trunks at night. The horns
are used to compete for this food. They have
wings, but their large size and heavy shells
limit their flight capability. Since they
buzz loudly while flying, you'll have an
easier time finding them if you keep your
ears open.

_FirstCapture: A Hercudrome subspecies with a shiny, golden\r\ncarapace. While they share their ecology with the\r\nbase species, these are significantly more rare.
_Memo:
A Hercudrome subspecies with a shiny, golden
carapace. Very few of these have been found,
and no one has figured out why the carapaces
are gold. However, the sightings span
several regions and these are classified
as a subspecies, not just a color variation.
Because of their beauty, they are in high
demand among collectors.

_FirstCapture: A member of the Hercudrome family with\r\nan iridescent carapace. The few confirmed\r\nsightings were in certain times or seasons.
_Memo:
A member of the Hercudrome family with an
iridescent carapace. Its pronotum is large
and developed, with three prominent horns.
Unlike ordinary Hercudromes, these inhabit
the Ruins of Wyveria. Alas, there have been
precious few sightings. Most have been at
dawn or dusk, so that might be the best
time to attempt and capture one.

_EnemyExp: Delicate insects that choose habitats that\r\nmonsters won\'t approach, making them good\r\nindicators of where to set up a Pop-up Camp.
_FirstCapture: Delicate insects that can be found in\r\nnearly any climate. They choose habitats\r\nthat monsters are unlikely to approach.
_Memo:
Flying insects that resemble four-leaf
clovers. Resilient to any weather, they can
be found day or night in nearly any climate
at places where monsters aren't likely to
prowl. Which is a good indicator that an
area is safe enough for a Pop-up Camp.

_FirstCapture: Butterflies that emerge at the start\r\nof the Plenty in large numbers, making\r\nthem a crucial part of the ecosystem.
_Memo:
Butterflies that hatch during the Plenty and
pupate near its close. Those that survive
the harsh Fallow emerge during the following
season of Plenty. They adapt their life cycle
to the Scarlet Forest, so if a population
hatches early, it may reach adulthood
within the same season. They feed a variety
of predatory organisms, including
insectivorous plants, making them a crucial
part of the ecosystem.

_FirstCapture: Brightly colored beetles with impressive\r\nshells that fan outward. They gather on the\r\ntrunks of trees in order to collect sap.
_Memo:
Brightly colored beetles with impressive
shells that fan outward. Each beetle's
coloring and shapes are different\u{2014}and with
their sparkle, it's no wonder they're
likened to gems. They tend to be diurnal,
gathering on the trunks of trees in hopes
of getting a nip of sap.

_FirstCapture: Jewel Scarabs with larger, more developed\r\nshells. The vast differences from specimen to\r\nspecimen make them difficult to categorize.
_Memo:
The finest of Jewel Scarab specimens, with
larger, more developed shells. They are found
with the rest of their kind, feeding on sap,
but are near impossible to spot. While Jewel
Scarabs are known for variations in shape
and color, the Regal variants are a bit
harder to explain. Are they the result of
a particular larval diet? An acquired
mutation? Are they even the same species
at all? Only more research will tell.

_FirstCapture: Master weavers that ensnare prey using\r\nhuman-sized webs, but with an escape\r\nroute in case predators approach.
_Memo:
Master weavers that use webs to ensnare
prey. You will often see butterflies and
other insects caught in their webs, which
is as big as a person and is equipped
with an escape route for the Vaporonid
in case predators approach. The silk used
in the web is extremely sturdy and comes
in handy if you need to make pitfall traps
to ensnare a few monsters of your own.

_FirstCapture: Insects whose bellies glow yellow or red\r\nwhen they detect threats. They inhabit\r\nareas with abundant vegetation.
_Memo:
Insects whose bellies glow yellow or red
when they detect threats. Their resemblance
to fossils seems to suggest that Omenflies
have been around for quite a long time. The
glowing seems to be a warning to enemies.
Since Omenflies stay near the water, it is
believed they keep their larvae in the water
or in the moist soil nearby. Adults will stay
airborne for the majority of their lives.

_FirstCapture: Forest creatures that survive by disguising\r\nthemselves as plants. They can change\r\ndisguises to adapt to environmental changes.
_Memo:
Forest creatures that survive by using
mimicry to disguise themselves as plants,
confusing predators and luring in prey.
Mimiphyta change form in response to
seasonal and environmental changes; during
the Fallow, they'll snuggle up at the base
of a tree to live as fungi, while in the
season of Plenty they blossom into lovely
flowers and prey on butterflies and
insects that flutter near.

_FirstCapture: Creatures that live in cold climates, often in\r\nabandoned buildings. They watch passers-by\r\ncuriously while standing on their tails.
_Memo:
Creatures that live in cold climates, often
in abandoned buildings. Their slowness and
lack of defensive measures suggest they aren't
accustomed to threats. Perhaps because
of this, they're not very cautious and will
watch curiously while standing on their tails.
They also like to gnaw on hard things like
the Landspine to wear down their teeth.
They are omnivorous today, but it's possible
they fed on harder substances in the past.

_FirstCapture: Creatures that have adapted to living both\r\non land and in the water. At night, they\r\nlight up their luminous organs and cry out.
_Memo:
Creatures that have adapted to living both
on land and in the water. They are precious
evidence of how amphibious creatures might
have come to walk the earth. Scarlet
Joyperch become active at night, when they
light up the luminous organs near their
heads, spread their fins, and let out a cry\u{2014}
presumably their way of strutting their
stuff to other members of their kind.

_FirstCapture: An aquatic creature that has adapted to life\r\non land. It attracts prey with the light on\r\nits head.
_Memo:
Aquatic creatures that have adapted to life
on land. Though similar to the Andangler,
the shape of the light on their heads are
different and are designed to attract the
Sparklerjelly that float in the air of the
Oilwell Basin. Due to this, some theorize
that the Andangler and Blink Angler may
have evolved from other amphibious fish.

_FirstCapture: A nocturnal creature that piles\r\nplants on its cup-like carapace and\r\nburrows into the ground to hide.
_Memo:
Crabs that pile plants on their cup-like
carapaces and burrow into the ground to
hide from predators. Their claws are
shaped like shovels, allowing them to
burrow more easily. They generally remain
buried during the day, becoming active only
at night, where they can be found digging
for insects to eat.

_FirstCapture: A nocturnal creature that piles\r\nplants on its cup-like carapace and\r\nburrows into the ground to hide.
_Memo:
Crabs that pile oilsilt on their cup-like
carapaces and burrow into the ground
to hide from predators. Because oilsilt itself
changes appearance depending on the season,
it's theorized that these crabs must replace
their silt to match. They are rarely seen in
volcanic regions or during the Firespring,
suggesting that they aren't particularly
resistant to heat.

_FirstCapture: A Florashell Crab that has retained\r\nits ancient appearance. It flees at\r\nfull speed the instant it spots a foe.
_Memo:
Crabs that have retained their ancient
appearance and are bigger than their
standard brethren. They flee at full speed
the instant they spot a foe, not bothering
to camouflage themselves. Instead, they
heap metal objects onto their carapaces,
which are thought to be artifacts from
ancient civilizations.

_FirstCapture: Lizards with luminous organs. When\r\nattacked, they drop luminous material as\r\na decoy while they make a quick getaway.
_Memo:
Lizards with luminous organs around their
body. When attacked, they go dark and leave
luminous material in their wake as a decoy
while they make a quick getaway. From this
observation, it can be surmised that it's not
their epidermis that glows, but some other
substance stored in their bodies. In line
with these habits, Smokeshroud Gekkos can
generally be found in dark, gloomy places.

_FirstCapture: Lizards that prefer deep caves and other\r\nplaces that light doesn\'t easily reach. They\r\ncan live in even the harshest of climes.
_Memo:
Lizards that prefer deep caves and other
places that light doesn't easily reach. They
can even survive in volcanic habitats, proof
of their resilience in even the harshest of
climes. Their toxicity is unknown, but the
red and purple coloring of their skin is
believed to be a warning. They survive
by feeding on cave insects.

_FirstCapture: A species noted for its males who\r\ngrow spectacularly colorful plumage\r\nafter their molt to court females.
_Memo:
A species noted for its males, who don
spectacularly colorful plumage after
molting. During the Fallow, their plumage is
a subdued green to match the vegetation, but
once the Plenty arrives, males preen to the
nines, adopting a vibrant color palette\u{2014}
presumably to court females, since the more
flamboyant males with larger feathers seem
to be the ones flapping away with a date.

_FirstCapture: Male Dapperwings with bigger tails, brighter\r\nplumage, and some pretty good odds when\r\nit comes to courting the females.
_Memo:
Male Dapperwings with bigger tails, brighter
plumage, and some pretty darn good odds when
it comes to courting the females. Not only
that, it is believed the plumage the males
achieve after molting plays a vital role in
what traits they pass on to their offspring.

_FirstCapture: Nocturnal creatures that live in the desert.\r\nThey are extremely wary and use acute\r\nhearing to detect and flee from threats.
_Memo:
Nocturnal desert creatures with pale,
luminescent fur that is believed to be the
result of the insects they primarily feed on.
Highly vigilant, they use their excellent
hearing to detect approaching threats and
flee, so trying to chase one down is the
wrong approach. You'll have a far easier
time catching one if you use a sonic bomb
to disrupt its hearing.

_FirstCapture: A creature that is thought to have\r\noriginally been a wyvern but\r\nevolved to live in caves like a bat.
_Memo:
Creatures that greatly resemble bats. They
hang from the ceiling in dark places like
caves, and become active at night, preying
on insects and smaller flying creatures.
They can also be found in forests. Because
of characteristics like their scales, it is
theorized that they may have evolved from
wyverns. Huge colonies live in caves in the
Oilwell Basin, as evidenced by the piles
of dung found there.

_FirstCapture: A jellyfish that floats in the air, preying\r\nupon airborne microbes.
_Memo:
Jellyfish that float in the air. Often seen
around the Coral Highlands in the New World.
Environments that contain the airborne
microbes they feed on and the air currents
they use to get around are quite rare.
Because the yellow ones found in the Oilwell
Basin are all male and the larger, more
colorful Peony Sparklerjelly are all female,
it is theorized that they actually belong to
the same species.

_FirstCapture: A larger, rarer jellyfish that floats\r\nin the air.
_Memo:
Jellyfish that float in the air. They are
larger and more colorful than their yellow
brethren. The tiny beads of light within
them are actually eggs and larvae, so it's
believed that these creatures are entirely
female. This suggests that they belong to
the same species as the yellow Sparklerjelly,
which are entirely male. That being said,
it's exceptionally rare for jellyfish to have
such extreme differences between sexes.

_FirstCapture: The larva of a Nu Udra. Can be found\r\nfloating in the area at certain times.
_Memo:
The larva of a Nu Udra. Though a fully grown
Nu Udra hadn't been seen in a long time,
there have been glimpses of this larval form.
Not much is known about their breeding
cycles, but it seems many eggs will hatch at
once, meaning groups of the creature are not
uncommon. The distinctive pattern on their
heads appears to hide an underdeveloped
eyeball and seems to grow into better
support of the eye.

_FirstCapture: Xu Wu larvae. Their skin is transparent, and\r\nfeatures a pattern unique to each specimen.
_Memo:
Xu Wu larvae, newly hatched from their eggs.
They already give off a faint luminescence,
and patterns can be seen through their thin,
transparent skin. They generally move in
groups, but not in an organized manner\u{2014}
it's only because they hatched at the same
time. After hatching, the nutrients from
their eggs sustain them for a while. Beyond
that, their diet remains unknown.

_FirstCapture: Creatures with fins that help them move\r\nthrough the air. They\'re delicate but have\r\ntremendous regenerative capabilities.
_Memo:
Creatures with rippling fins on both sides
of their body that help them move through
the air. The fins possess a sort of
circulatory system, similar to blood
vessels, that give off light. Because their
bodies are so fragile, even the slightest
shock or gust of wind can tear them apart.
Their regenerative abilities make up for
this, however, as each piece becomes
a separate individual.

_FirstCapture: Creatures that survive by attaching to the\r\nWyrmway, using energy-receptive organs along\r\ntheir abdomens to harvest its energy.
_Memo:
Creatures that survive by attaching to the
Wyrmway, using energy-receptive organs along
their abdomens to harvest its energy. This
specialized adaptation, and its other traits
that are consistent with ancient organisms,
makes this species a fascinating subject of
study. For example, their vision and nervous
systems are highly developed for such a
simple body structure, a detail that invites
further investigation.

_FirstCapture: A special type of Pillopod with a larger\r\nbody and prominent, expanded energy\r\ncirculation system.
_Memo:
A special type of Pillopod with a larger
body and prominent, expanded energy
circulation system. Their eyes are
compressed, suggesting a mutation caused
by excessive energy intake. However,
considering how little is known about
ordinary Pillopods, these mysteries may
take some time to elucidate.

_FirstCapture: Insects found in abundance in the Ruins\r\nof Wyveria. While they are poor fliers,\r\nthey use the wind to get around.
_Memo:
Insects found in areas with ample vegetation
such as the heart of the Ruins of Wyveria.
Petalflies have poor flight capabilities,
but they can still use the wind to get
around. The larvae live in water or on moist
ground until they mature, while an adult's
short life span is spent reproducing. It has
been suggested that the flowery fragrance
the Petalflies give off may be a pheromone
linked to mating.

_FirstCapture: Birds that can be sighted riding on the\r\nbacks of small monsters. They are extremely\r\nwary of threats and are quick to flee,
_Memo:
Birds that can be sighted riding on the
backs of small monsters. They are extremely
wary of external threats and are quick to
flee, making them difficult to capture.
Their disproportionately long legs allow
them to move at high speeds. Populations
have been observed living in some human
settlements, allowing their eggs to be
gathered in an extremely unusual symbiotic
relationship.

_EnemyExp: A small fish that moves in large schools. It is common\r\nin bodies of water of the Windward Plains and the Forest.\r\nNotable for its bright, reflective blue and gold scales.
_FirstCapture: A small fish that is common prey for many\r\ncreatures and prefers to live in schools.\r\nThe schools can become impressively large.
_Memo:
Small fish with blue and yellow scales that
prefer to live in schools. The sizes of
these schools vary and at times can become
impressively large. Because they both breed
rapidly and exist in large numbers, they are
frequently preyed upon, making them the
backbone of the ecosystem. Splashes on the
surface of bodies of water are a sign of
this fish fleeing from large predators.

_EnemyExp: A fish whose physiology remains almost\r\nunchanged from its ancient ancestors.\r\nIts spiny fins help ward off predators.
_FirstCapture: A species endemic to the Eastlands. They are\r\nmore common in warm areas and are noted for\r\ntheir bright green bodies.
_Memo:
A species endemic to the Eastlands. They are
more common in warm areas, suggesting
that they have adapted to more temperate
climates. Compared to other fish, Virid
Bowfins are neither particularly useful nor
suitable for eating, so anglers tend to
treat them as bycatch. On the other hand,
they have high scientific value because they
exhibit unique traits not seen outside their
Eastland habitat.

_EnemyExp: A fish with a dorsal fin\r\nhard enough to be used\r\nto sharpen weapons.
_FirstCapture: Fish with scales and fins hard enough to surpass\r\ncommon whetstones. The fins in particular are\r\nfrequently used for sharpening.
_Memo:
Fish covered with scales and fins of
considerable durability. In fact, Whetfish
are so hard that they are often used in
place of common whetstones to sharpen
weapons. It is believed these hardened
features evolved as a defense mechanism
against predators. They show a strong
interest in Emerald Jitterbait.

_EnemyExp: Sushifish are a popular hunter staple.\r\nTheir nutrient-rich scales can also be\r\nused to restore health.
_FirstCapture: A popular food source high in nutrition.\r\nTheir scales are capable of restoring\r\nhealth.
_Memo:
A popular food source found in many
a hunter's pouch, these fish have very
high nutritional value\u{2014}not just in their
flesh, but their scales too. They offer
a remarkable range of benefits, including
health and bleeding recovery, and stamina
boosts. Because of this, Sushifish are common
prey for many aquatic species. They show
a strong interest in Emerald Jitterbait.

_FirstCapture: Large fish with a habit of gobbling up\r\neverything they see\u{2014}including a hunter\'s\r\ntools.
_Memo:
Large fish that gobble up anything and
everything they can swallow, including
things a hunter might use for tools.
Gastronome Tuna are commonly observed
during the season of Plenty, when smaller
fish are abundant. Food is scarce during
the Fallow, however, so sightings become
rare as they move to more fruitful feeding
grounds. They show a strong interest in
Tuff Joint Bait.

_FirstCapture: Fish with flat heads, broad mouths, and\r\nlong whiskers. They are known to grow\r\nto a considerable size.
_Memo:
Large fish with flat heads, broad mouths,
